image.altText: A blonde lady smiles in a portrait style photo

items.synopsis: WA's police commissioner pledges to review the circumstances of the night Lynn Cannon was stabbed to death by her estranged partner, amid questions over why it took officers an hour and 15 minutes to arrive at the scene.

title.children: Police decisions on night of 'savage' Lynn Cannon murder will be reviewed, commissioner says

image.altText: Twenty-year-old Johnson Kokozian wearing a cap looking at the camera and smiling

items.synopsis: NSW Police also confirms two more people had been arrested in relation to the crash.

title.children: Driver accused of killing siblings in Sydney crash has dangerous driving charges upgraded

image.altText: rundle mall shoppers in rundle mall

items.synopsis: Australia's economy is growing at an annual pace of 2.1 per cent, down from 2.7 per cent at the end of 2022.

title.children: Australia's economy continued to slow in June quarter, households finding it harder to save

image.altText: a bown/green turtle on sand with sun behind

items.synopsis: About 100 metres from the end of a runway earmarked to take spy planes for the Australian Defence Force and its allies, hundreds of vulnerable turtles are starving and dying.

title.children: Hundreds of turtles are dying on a tiny coral atoll that's key to Australia's defence ambitions

image.altText: A man looks straight ahead with green tinted sunglasses on

items.synopsis: Prosecutors say they are awaiting results of a post-mortem examination of Clare Nowland, 95, who died after allegedly being tasered by police officer Kristian White.

title.children: Officer accused of tasering Cooma great-grandmother Clare Nowland faces court in person

image.altText: young girl on bus.

items.synopsis: From war-torn hills and valleys, to the sheep and wheat paddocks of Western Australia's south, the Karen people are determined to pass down their language and traditions to the next generation.

title.children: The remote West Australian school where Karen refugees are free to celebrate their culture

image.altText: Four Corners obtained footage showing the tear gassing of boys being held in isolation at the Don Dale Youth Detention Centre in Darwin, in August 201

items.synopsis: A Supreme Court justice orders the NT government to pay more than $200,000 each to four men who were tear gassed when still teenagers in the Darwin detention facility.

title.children: NT government ordered to pay nearly $1 million to former Don Dale inmates tear gassed in 2014

image.altText: A mother and father holding their young daughter between them, smiling. They are standing on an apartment balcony.

items.synopsis: Medium- and high-density development in established suburbs is being spruiked as the solution to Australia's housing crisis. But there are still some risks.

title.children: Sean and Jane paid $720,000 for an apartment with no car parks and shared laundry. It was their path out of renting

image.altText: A woman with blue shirt and name tag sits looking up at and holding the knee of a woman who sits on a raised bed.

items.synopsis: Australia has one of the world's best healthcare systems. But senior physician Fiona Reilly argues it doesn't always work as well as it should for patients.

title.children: It only takes 11 seconds for a GP to interrupt a patient. A simple shift could change things

image.altText: Promo image of a line chart showing housing costs broken down by income.

items.synopsis: Housing costs are at record highs, and we can show you who is bearing the brunt of the crisis.

title.children: Where you sit on this chart determines your level of housing stress

image.altText: Close up on hundreds of bees.

items.synopsis: WA's peak industry body for beekeeping believes there's a "huge risk" of the deadly parasite entering the state via freight link traffic or swarms of feral bees — but authorities are "incredibly confident" it can be kept out.

title.children: WA beekeepers fear biosecurity 'complacency' has left state ill-prepared for a varroa mite outbreak

image.altText: Vanessa Hudson, the incoming Qantas CEO, with model plane in foreground showing Flying Kangaroo

items.synopsis: With Alan Joyce announcing his abrupt departure from Qantas two months ahead of schedule, Vanessa Hudson is now in control of an airline with a reputation problem — and disgruntled customers say it will be tough to win them back.

title.children: New Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson faces an uphill battle to restore the public's faith as Alan Joyce departs

image.altText: An intense bushfire burns across a large rural area.

items.synopsis: Donnybrook resident says the sleepless nights when he and his family defended their South West WA property are difficult to forget as they learn from their experience eight months ago.

title.children: Farmer's nervous wait for bushfire season after learning hard lesson in respect

image.altText: A man lays in a hospital bed as an elderly woman holds his hand

items.synopsis: Gavin Hicks was spooked by the death of professional cyclist Jason Lowndes on a road outside Bendigo. Six years later, he was seriously injured in a collision on the same road.

title.children: Cyclist hit by car on same Victorian road where elite rider died calls for new speed limit

image.altText: Two men look at the camera. They are standing on land.

items.synopsis: The sailors were attempting a continuous circumnavigation on an inflatable boat when sharks got the better of their vessel. They say it wasn't the first shark attack on their boat.

title.children: Expeditioners rescued after boat attacked by sharks in Coral Sea

image.altText: A middle-aged man holds a long stick up in a prayer position in front of his face

items.synopsis: Taiwan's iPhone billionaire is running for president with a lofty election promise to broker peace between Taiwan and China. But observers believe his election bid may result in a less China-friendly candidate securing the presidency.

title.children: Taiwan's iPhone billionaire is shaking up the island’s presidential election in his bid to fulfil the wishes of a sea goddess

image.altText: A man in a dark suit walks down a corridor holding a coffee cup with another man beside him.

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says there is no need to review the rejection of Qatar's application for more flights to major Australian airports, despite a forthcoming Senate inquiry.

title.children: 'No intention' to review Qatar Airways decision despite Senate inquiry

image.altText: Elon Musk with his hands clasped together.

items.synopsis: Mr Musk says the platform X, formerly Twitter, had been losing revenue due to the Anti-Defamation League scaring away advertisers.

title.children: Elon Musk plans to sue Anti-Defamation League over X losing revenue

image.altText: A man dressed in black and yellow tactical gear smokes a cigarette in front of an American flag

items.synopsis: The former leader of the far-right group, which stormed Washington's Capitol to stop the congress certifying Joe Biden, begged for mercy before being sentenced.

title.children: Proud Boys leader breaks down in court and pleads for mercy before being jailed for 22 years over Capitol riots

image.altText: A woman's hands holding two shells, seen from above

items.synopsis: A vast collection of Indigenous artefacts kept in England for decades is being returned to the Northern Territory, ending an "emotional" years-long repatriation process.

title.children: 'The first time I saw them it made me cry': Indigenous artefacts returned after decades in English museum

image.altText: Man in blue suit stands in front of Israeli flag

items.synopsis: Israel will pay for Papua New Guinea to operate the embassy it opened in the contested city of Jerusalem, according to PNG's Prime Minister.

title.children: Israel to bankroll PNG embassy in the contested city of Jerusalem, PM says

image.altText: Albanese stands speaking to media from a courtyard.

items.synopsis: The PM will use a speech to the ASEAN summit on Wednesday to release the government's South-East Asian Economic Strategy, a blueprint aimed at driving trade and investment north into the region.

title.children: Anthony Albanese starts summit season talking trade ties and regional security, with China in mind

image.altText: Two male soldiers in slouch hats and formal uniform

items.synopsis: More than two years after Craftsman Brendon Payne and Warrant Officer Ryan Leslie were killed during a training exercise, the Department of Defence has been charged with failing to ensure their health and safety. The charge carries a maximum penalty of $1.5 million.

title.children: Defence charged over 2021 truck rollover that killed two soldiers

image.altText: A woman in a grocery isle of fruit and vegetables

items.synopsis: The latest GDP data shows an annual slowdown in the Australian economy because of interest rate hikes.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Economy grows by 2.1 per cent in 12 months, Wall Street falls, Australian dollar tumbles

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Not surprisingly Treasurer Jim Chalmers has given an upbeat response to the latest GDP figures, despite warning about the uncertainty faced by the Australian economy because of higher interest rates and a slowing China. The rise of 0.4 per cent over the June quarter, matched a 0.4 per cent increase over the March quarter. However growth pulled back over the year to June with the economy expanding by 2.1 per cent. Here's what Mr Chalmers had to say: "The Australian economy remains steady and sturdy in the face of unrelenting pressure." "Economic growth held up well despite the inevitable toll of higher interest rates, moderating inflation and continuing global uncertainty particularly as it relates to China." "We know that there are challenges ahead but we face them from a position of relative strength." Mr Chalmers noted that the high cost of living is weighing on consumers with housing spending growing by just 0.1 per cent over the quarter. "Australians continue to pull back on discretionary spending to make room for essentials and also to cover mortgage repayments." "People are also spending less on renovating their homes and are saving less out of their incomes, "We expect the economy to slow considerably over the next year and we expect the unemployment rate to tick up as well."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer says economy remains "steady and sturdy"

children.content: Not surprisingly Treasurer Jim Chalmers has given an upbeat response to the latest GDP figures, despite warning about the uncertainty faced by the Australian economy because of higher interest rates and a slowing China.
The rise of 0.4 per cent over the June quarter, matched a 0.4 per cent increase over the March quarter.
However growth pulled back over the year to June with the economy expanding by 2.1 per cent.
Here's what Mr Chalmers had to say:
"The Australian economy remains steady and sturdy in the face of unrelenting pressure."
"Economic growth held up well despite the inevitable toll of higher interest rates, moderating inflation and continuing global uncertainty particularly as it relates to China."
"We know that there are challenges ahead but we face them from a position of relative strength."
Mr Chalmers noted that the high cost of living is weighing on consumers with housing spending growing by just 0.1 per cent over the quarter.
"Australians continue to pull back on discretionary spending to make room for essentials and also to cover mortgage repayments."
"People are also spending less on renovating their homes and are saving less out of their incomes,
"We expect the economy to slow considerably over the next year and we expect the unemployment rate to tick up as well."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Consumers are pulling back on spending as higher interest rates and inflation bite, although the latest economic growth figures show a rise in government and business investment. The economy expanded by 0.4 per cent over the June quarter and by 2.1 per cent over the year to June according to the Bureau of Statistics. Services exports rose 12.1 percent driven by travel services as the number of international students and tourists returned as Australia continued to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. Sean Langcake from BIS Oxford Economics says net exports bounced back over the June quarter with good weather seeing an increase in mining shipments. Higher population growth is expanding the economy, but income per person has fallen for the second quarter in a row, essentially a per capita recession. The ABS says that population growth due to post-pandemic migration saw GDP per capital fall 0.3 per cent, following a similar fall of 0.3 per cent in March. Here's Mr Langcake; "Household consumption growth is in the doldrums,      increasing by just 0.1 per cent quarter on quarter." "Spending on discretionary items continues to      fall, with vehicle purchases a lone bright spot. " "Spending on essentials remains      steady, buoyed by the relatively strong pace of population growth."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumers pull back but businesses keep spending

children.content: Consumers are pulling back on spending as higher interest rates and inflation bite, although the latest economic growth figures show a rise in government and business investment.
The economy expanded by 0.4 per cent over the June quarter and by 2.1 per cent over the year to June according to the Bureau of Statistics.
Services exports rose 12.1 percent driven by travel services as the number of international students and tourists returned as Australia continued to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic.
Sean Langcake from BIS Oxford Economics says net exports bounced back over the June quarter with good weather seeing an increase in mining shipments.
Higher population growth is expanding the economy, but income per person has fallen for the second quarter in a row, essentially a
per capita recession
The ABS says that population growth due to post-pandemic migration saw GDP per capital fall 0.3 per cent, following a similar fall of 0.3 per cent in March.
Here's Mr Langcake;
"Household consumption growth is in the doldrums,      increasing by just 0.1 per cent quarter on quarter."
"Spending on discretionary items continues to      fall, with vehicle purchases a lone bright spot. "
"Spending on essentials remains      steady, buoyed by the relatively strong pace of population growth."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Chief economist at BetaShares, David Bassanese, has just shared his initial take on today's GDP and national accounts figures. He says the results were "stronger than expected" despite the weaker growth in household spending, but it " highlights the tensions that continue to exist between monetary and fiscal policy settings in Australia ". Here's his full take on the figures and their meaning: "National GDP grew by 0.4% in the June quarter, or a touch above the 0.3% gain expected by the market. Over the past twelve months, the economy has posted modestly below trend growth of 2.1%. "Yet within the national accounts, household consumer spending grew by a mere 0.1% in the June quarter, to be up only 1.5% over the past year. Higher interest rates, courtesy of the RBA, are certainly doing their part in slowing down the consumer, which is a big chunk (50%) of the economy. "Higher interest rates, along with ongoing labour and material shortages, have also helped slow housing construction, which fell 0.2% in the quarter and by 1.1% over the past year. "Yet countering this effect has been strength in public demand. In particular, new public investment spending rose by 5.5% in the quarter, which as the ABS notes, reflects "ongoing large-scale transport, health and education projects across a number of states ." Indeed, major public infrastructure programs are also likely contributing to the labour and material shortages in the housing sector — adding to inflationary pressure and "crowding out" much needed growth in housing supply. "While federal and state government commitment to infrastructure programs is usually a welcome development, the present timing of this public investment boom is unfortunate – as it runs contrary to the RBA's efforts to slow the economy and bring down inflation. "All that said, today's stronger than expected GDP report is not expected to change the outlook for the RBA just yet ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Economic growth figures highlight the 'tensions' between monetary and fiscal policy

children.content: Chief economist at BetaShares,
David Bassanese
, has just shared his initial take on today's GDP and national accounts figures.
He says the results were "stronger than expected" despite the weaker growth in household spending, but it "
highlights the tensions that continue to exist between monetary and fiscal policy settings in Australia
Here's his full take on the figures and their meaning:
"National GDP grew by 0.4% in the June quarter, or a touch above the 0.3% gain expected by the market. Over the past twelve months, the economy has posted modestly below trend growth of 2.1%.
"Yet within the national accounts, household consumer spending grew by a mere 0.1% in the June quarter, to be up only 1.5% over the past year.
Higher interest rates, courtesy of the RBA, are certainly doing their part in slowing down the consumer, which is a big chunk (50%) of the economy.
"Higher interest rates, along with ongoing labour and material shortages, have also helped slow housing construction, which fell 0.2% in the quarter and by 1.1% over the past year.
"Yet countering this effect has been
strength in public demand
. In particular, new public investment spending rose by 5.5% in the quarter, which as the ABS notes, reflects
"ongoing large-scale transport, health and education projects across a number of states
." Indeed, major public infrastructure programs are also likely contributing to the labour and material shortages in the housing sector —
adding to inflationary pressure and "crowding out" much needed growth in housing supply
"While federal and state government commitment to infrastructure programs is usually a welcome development,
the present timing of this public investment boom is unfortunate – as it runs contrary to the RBA's efforts to slow the economy and bring down inflation
"All that said, today's stronger than expected GDP report is
not expected to change the outlook for the RBA just yet

image.altText: RBA governor Philip Lowe speaks at the Morgan Stanley Australia summit in Sydney

items.synopsis: The public service code of conduct sets out reasons why a Reserve Bank governor should not move to a private bank at the end of the term. But there is nothing to stop Philip Lowe doing so and — as shabby as it seems — he wouldn't be the first, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: With his last interest rates decision made, will Philip Lowe move to a private bank?

image.altText: A computer screen showing Chinese company Baidu AI chatbot generating image of cat.

items.synopsis: Ernie Bot, a generative AI chatbot, is now fully accessible to the public. But how powerful can it be in a realm of heavily censored internet use, and how does this fit into China's vision of becoming the world leader in AI?

title.children: 'Layers of censorship': Ernie Bot is China's answer to ChatGPT – is it AI's 'great leap forward'?

image.altText: Courtroom sketch of bald man

items.synopsis: Top security measures are employed in the trial of an infamous criminal, whose jailbreak case allegedly included helicopters, smoke grenades and circular power saws.

title.children: France's notorious 'getaway king' faces trial for dramatic chopper jailbreak

image.altText: Green banana bunches hang upside down in a shed as a man wearing a bright orange cap tends to a bunch.

items.synopsis: Ecuador is wedged between the world's largest cocaine producers, Peru and Colombia, with drug traffickers finding containers filled with bananas to be the perfect vehicle to smuggle their product.

title.children: Security in Ecuador comes undone as drug cartels exploit banana industry to ship cocaine

image.altText: two photos of a filthy bedroom

items.synopsis: The disability royal commission found the abuse and neglect faced by two brothers was sometimes "mistaken for disability-related behaviours". Warning: This story contains content that readers may find distressing.

title.children: ‘Violence, abuse, neglect and deprivation of human rights’: Shocking details from Brisbane’s house of horrors revealed

image.altText: Mitchell Marsh and David Warner bump fists.

items.synopsis: Mitch Marsh concedes he expects to drop into the middle order for the World Cup, saying there is no way David Warner should not open the batting.

title.children: 'He's one of the GOATs': Marsh backs Warner to open the batting for Australia at the World Cup

image.altText: A man looks on, waving his arms

items.synopsis: Spain's beleaguered football federation sacks the coach of its national women's team, Jorge Vilda, less than three weeks after he oversaw its World Cup triumph in Australia.

title.children: Spain sacks World Cup-winning women's coach as post-tournament chaos continues

image.altText: A small chimpanzee on a rope

items.synopsis: The three-year-old chimpanzee — whose surrogate mother rushed to his aid and refused to let go — is recovering after being bitten by the deadly snake in his enclosure at Rockhampton Zoo.

title.children: Gandali the chimp survives snakebite at Queensland zoo after mistaking eastern brown for toy
